title: Peter Mweshihange
text:
Peter Mweshihange (5 May 1930 – 20 March 1998) was a <a href="Namibia">Namibia</a>n revolutionary and <a href="guerrilla">guerrilla</a> leader, and after <a href="Namibian%20War%20of%20Independence">Namibian independence</a>, a politician and diplomat. He was the first Namibia's minister of defense from 1990 to 1995, and first ambassador to the <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">People's Republic of China</a> from 1996 until his death.
Early life.
Mweshihange was born as fifth of twenty-five children on 5 May 1930 in <a href="Epinga">Epinga</a> near the border with <a href="Angola">Angola</a> in former <a href="Ovamboland">Ovamboland</a>, today <a href="Ohangwena%20Region">Ohangwena Region</a>. 
In his childhood years, he developed knowledge of the local <a href="flora">flora</a> and considered himself to be a <a href="traditional%20healer">traditional healer</a>, using his childhood friends as <a href="Human%20subject%20research">guinea pig</a>s. He attended St. Mary's Mission School at <a href="Odibo">Odibo</a> from the age of 11, and from the age of 14 he received training to become a teacher. He moved to <a href="Tsumeb">Tsumeb</a> in 1946 and worked first as truck driver, then as head of transport services at the <a href="South%20West%20Africa%20Native%20Labour%20Association">South West Africa Native Labour Association</a> (SWANLA), the colonial labour hire company of <a href="South-West%20Africa">South-West Africa</a>.
Mweshihange was arrested in <a href="Rundu">Rundu</a> in 1954 on his first attempt to go into exile. He was not convicted, but left South-West Africa soon afterwards to work as miner in <a href="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a> and as <a href="chef">chef</a> for the French consul-general in <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a>. He joined the resistance movement there and followed <a href="Sam%20Nujoma">Sam Nujoma</a> into <a href="Tanganyika%20%28territory%29">Tanganyika</a>n exile in 1960.
Career.
Exile years.
The first years in exile Mweshihange furthered his education, studying towards a teacher's training certificate at Kivukoni Training College in <a href="Dar%20es%20Salaam">Dar es Salaam</a> in 1961 and 1962, and political science and ideology in <a href="Ghana">Ghana</a> in 1963 and 1964. Together with Nujoma he managed <a href="SWAPO">SWAPO</a>'s administration and resistance strategy, attempting to intensify the struggle for independence. From this attempt emerged the start of armed <a href="guerrilla">guerrilla</a> action against the <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>n occupiers, and in 1966 the <a href="Namibian%20War%20of%20Independence">Namibian War of Independence</a> started with a South African assault at <a href="Omugulugwombashe">Omugulugwombashe</a> in northern Namibia.
At that time, Mweshihange was a commander in the <a href="People%27s%20Liberation%20Army%20of%20Namibia">People's Liberation Army of Namibia</a> (PLAN), the armed wing of SWAPO. Within the party structure he rose to the position of Secretary of Internal Affairs in 1970 and subsequently went to the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> to receive military training. In 1986 he became SWAPO's Secretary of Defense, responsible for PLAN's strategy to conduct the <a href="Namibian%20War%20of%20Independence">War of Independence</a>. He was responsible for supervising PLAN operations during the decisive <a href="Battle%20of%20Cuito%20Cuanavale">Battle of Cuito Cuanavale</a>.
After Namibian independence.
Mweshihange was a member of the SWAPO <a href="Central%20Committee">Central Committee</a> and <a href="Politburo">Politburo</a> since the early days of the <a href="Ovamboland%20People%27s%20Congress">Ovamboland People's Congress</a>, of which he was a co-founder. 
At the time of independence in 1990, Mweshihange was <a href="1989%20Namibian%20parliamentary%20election">elected</a> as one of the <a href="members%20of%20the%20Constituent%20Assembly%20of%20Namibia">members of the Constituent Assembly of Namibia</a> with SWAPO, and appointed Minister of Defense. 
In 1996, he became Namibia's first <a href="Namibian%20Ambassador%20to%20China">ambassador to the People's Republic of China</a>, a position he held until his death. 
He died on 20 March 1998 while on a home visit to <a href="Windhoek">Windhoek</a>. Peter Mweshihange was given a <a href="state%20funeral">state funeral</a> at Windhoek's <a href="Old%20Location">Old Location</a> Cemetery, and later re-buried at the <a href="Heroes%27%20Acre%20%28Namibia%29">Namibian National Heroes' Acre</a>. <a href="Theo-Ben%20Gurirab">Theo-Ben Gurirab</a> remembered him as a culinary master and "connoisseur of good things in life".
